title: Nadine Gordimer - Nobel Prize in Literature, 1991 (29 books)
description:
NADINE GORDIMER (1923-2014) was a South African writer, anti-apartheid activist and recipient of the 1991 Nobel Prize in Literature for "her magnificent epic writing [that] has -- in the words of Alfred Nobel -- been of very great benefit to humanity."

Gordimer achieved lasting international recognition for works that have been described as "history from the inside", dealing with moral and racial issues, particularly the devastating impact of apartheid on the lives of all South Africans.  Through her novels, short stories, and essays, Gordimer revealed the prejudices and ideologies, the tensions and stresses of life in a racially divided society and the corrupting and corrosive effects of the apartheid system.  Always questioning power relations and truth, she tells stories of ordinary people, revealing moral ambiguities and choices.  Her characterization is nuanced, revealed more through the choices her characters make than through their claimed identities and beliefs.

Gordimer's activism was not limited to the struggle against apartheid.  She resisted censorship and state control of information, and fostered the literary arts.  A founding member of the Congress of South African Writers, Gordimer was also active in South African letters and international literary organizations, serving as Vice President of International PEN.  In the post-apartheid 1990s and 21st century, Gordimer was active in the HIV/AIDS movement, addressing a significant public health crisis in South Africa.

In addition to the Nobel Prize, she was the recipient of prestigious literary awards in South Africa, Europe, and the U.S., including a number of annual CNA Literary Awards in South Africa, the W.H. Smith Literary Award, the James Tait Black Memorial Prize, the Booker Prize and the Grand Aigle d'Or.  In 2007 Gordimer was awarded the French Legion of Honour.
